issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: The described issue is not actually a problem - it is as designed.
resolution.name: Not A Problem

fields.summary: Change the semantics of @Slow on tests

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

issuetype.description: A task that needs to be done.
issuetype.name: Task

assignee.name: dweiss
assignee.emailAddress: dawid dot weiss at gmail dot com

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

components.name: general/test
components.description: issues with test related code (core or modules)

comments.body:
I calculated simple stats from a dozen test runs on my build machine (trunk at Jun 28, 2012).

h3. The slowest tests (mean time, stddev)

{noformat}
name                                       | mean    | stddev | min    | max
BasicDistributedZkTest                     | 168155  | 12697  | 136591 | 192507
FullSolrCloudTest                          | 95912   | 5867   | 76449  | 102628
OverseerTest                               | 95801   | 9025   | 82868  | 108840
RecoveryZkTest                             | 82924   | 13524  | 63800  | 115504
TestJoinUtil                               | 69328   | 74451  | 7358   | 268199
SpellCheckComponentTest                    | 65744   | 14222  | 38798  | 85575
FullSolrCloudDistribCmdsTest               | 49543   | 2837   | 45376  | 53916

TestLBHttpSolrServer                       | 35746   | 704    | 34841  | 37133
LeaderElectionTest                         | 33766   | 6039   | 23574  | 45419
DistributedSpellCheckComponentTest         | 30688   | 3500   | 23605  | 36914

comments.body: This is just informational. It'd be nice to have those slowest tests run a bit faster though. Or maybe move them to @Nightly since they're so long to execute?
